Award.AwardTitle: SaTC: EDU: Establishing Digital Citizenship by Implementing Cyber Safety Curriculum with Middle School Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project from the University of North Carolina at Charlotte will prepare students to demonstrate digital citizenship and cyber safety. The goal of this project is to increase cyber safety knowledge and skills among middle school students, teachers, and technology facilitators, while creating cyber safety awareness among parents of middle school students. This project will assist in designing a suite of instructional materials and application activities (e.g., e-learning modules, online course and videos) dedicated to bridge the gap in cyber safety education in schools. The project will also provide interdisciplinary research experiences in cyber safety, technology education, and pedagogical practices to both graduate and undergraduate students.

The proposed project will address the following objectives: 1) develop five e-learning modules on cyber safety topics (e.g., cyber bullying, digital footprints, digital identity, digital privacy and digital Netiquette) to communicate the importance of digital citizenship to the students; (2) design and deliver an online course on digital citizenship to 20 technology facilitators and 30 middle school teachers; (3) apply the train-the-trainer model by which the technology facilitators will train the teachers in their schools and classroom teachers train the students after the summer course on digital citizenship; (4) pilot the cyber safety e-learning modules with 200 middle school students in three different school districts and a charter school; and (5) help students create videos on cyber safety and disseminate the videos to their parents and a larger audience through social media. The instructional modules and online course content created will be shared with institutions outside the current scope of the project. Further, the project will establish a teacher education and training pipeline to attract more K-12 educators to the program, equip them with much needed cyber security knowledge and skills, and prepare them for the challenges of educating the next generation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Establishing Digital Citizenship by Implementing Cyber Safety Curriculum with Middle School Students was a three-year, $300 million National Science Foundation (NSF) grant. The goal of this grant was to increase digital citizenship and cyber safety knowledge and skills among middle school students and teachers and create cyber safety awareness among of parents of middle school students.The NSF grant (1723746) was awarded in 2017 to a team from University of North Carolina at Charlotte.

Project Objectives: The project objectives were to develop e-learning modules on cyber safety; design and deliver an online digital citizenship course to K-12 educators; apply train-the-trainer model; implement cyber safety e-learning modules with middle school students; create and disseminate student created cyber safety videos. All these objectives were met.  As a result of these objectives, the project provided research opportunities to project team members and graduate students and educational opportunities to graduate students, middle school students and teachers.

K-12 Educators and Middle School Students: Though a large amount of security education materials for college students and graduate students have been designed, digital safety education for middle school students is still an area of need. This project bridged the gap by developing and delivering modules to middle school students and teachers. Five elearning modules were created and implemented with 380 middle school students. A summer course on digital citizenship was developed and offered to 45 K-12 educators. Through training the trainers workshops, fourteen educators conducted workshops to disseminate the digital citizenship topics to other teachers in their schools and school district. Cyber safety e-learning modules were implemented with 380 students in three schools. A video competition was organized among middle school students. Thirteen students created a video regarding digital safety, and these videos were shared with others and the best videos were awarded prizes.

Graduate Students: The project team met monthly to achieve the project goals. The team mentored a graduate student who designed the e-learning modules. The student presented the modules to the team and revised the modules multiple times after receiving feedback from the project team. Thus, digital citizenship e-learning modules were created. In addition, a female, minority PhD student has been trained by the project to support with data collection and research. This promoted under-represented graduate students to participate in research.

Project Team: During the development and delivery, researchers in both domains of cybersecurity and education collaborated closely. Security education faculty member learned how to adapt the materials for younger audiences who face the same security challenges, while educational faculty learn how to integrate latest advances in security and technology into middle school classrooms.

Student and Teacher Module Access: All the course modules for the students and the online course for teachers that we developed are available online at https://dcc.uncc.edu/ for easy access and use. Since the material is offered through open access platforms, no extra cost will be incurred to the middle schools.

Research: Four publications in Educational Technology and Society, Computers in the Schools (2 articles), and Journal of Research on Technology in Education resulted from this project. In addition, seven presentations highlighted the results from this project to a broad audience in Teacher Education, Educational Technology and Cybersecurity. The details of the research activities can be accessed at https://dcc.uncc.edu/research
